XIV Central potentials

The isotropic harmonic oscillator is an example of a spherical symmetric potential, where the potential energy only depends on the radial distance from the origin, r=|ğ«|. These potentials are called central potentials. Another example is the Coulomb potential

Vc=q1â¢q24â¢Ï€â¢Îµ0â¢r (235)

of two charges q1 and q2. For central potentials the SchrÃ¶dinger equation

can also be separated in three one-dimensional problems, but only when one works in spherical polar coordinates. Note: Here mass is denoted by the symbol Î¼ since we need m later for a different purpose.

XIV.4 Quantisation of angular momentum

The angular momentum operator is given by ğ‹^=ğ«^Ã—ğ©^, hence L^x=y^â¢p^z-z^â¢p^y etc. The squared length is given by ğ‹^2=L^x2+L^y2+L^z2. One can show that

ğ‹^2â¢Ylâ¢mâ¢(Î¸,Ï•)=â„2â¢lâ¢(l+1)â¢Ylâ¢m, (257)
L^zâ¢Ylâ¢mâ¢(Î¸,Ï•)=â„â¢mâ¢Ylâ¢m. (258)

XIV.5 Degeneracy of the radial part

Equation (243) for the radial part Râ¢(r) depends on the potential and hence has to be solved separately for every problem in order to find the energies E. However, since this equation only depends on the azimuthal quantum number l but not on the magnetic quantum number m, each energy level is at least 2â¢l+1 fold degenerate, since for each l there are 2â¢l+1 solutions Ylâ¢m of the angular equation with different values of m.
